review.title: Learning-based Surgical Workflow Detection from Intra-Operative Signals
review.abstract: A modern operating room (OR) provides a plethora of advanced medical devices. In order to better facilitate the information offered by them, they need to automatically react to the intra-operative context. To this end, the progress of the surgical workflow must be detected and interpreted, so that the current status can be given in machine-readable form. In this work, Random Forests (RF) and Hidden Markov Models (HMM) are compared and combined to detect the surgical workflow phase of a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Various combinations of data were tested, from using only raw sensor data to filtered and augmented datasets. Achieved accuracies ranged from 64% to 72% for the RF approach, and from 80% to 82% for the combination of RF and HMM.

metadata.title: Learning-based Surgical Workflow Detection from Intra- Operative Signals

sections.text: In order to make better use of the information they provide, they must respond automatically to the intraoperative context. To this end, the progress of the surgical workflow must be recognized and interpreted so that the current status can be given in machine-readable form. In this work, Random Forests (RF) and Hidden Markov Models (HMM) are compared and combined to detect the surgical workflow phase of laparoscopic cholectomy. Various data combinations were tested, from the use of pure sensor data to filtered and expanded data sets. Accuracy ranged from 64% to 72% for the RF approach and from 80% to 82% for the combination of RF and HMM. Keywords: Surgical Data Science, Random Forest, Hidden Markov Model.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Automatic detection and recognition of the ongoing surgical process is a crucial step towards a more context-sensitive and collaborative operating theatre of the future. [1] Although it is generally a positive development that more and more medical and imaging equipment is available during surgery, this unfortunately also increases the surgeon's cognitive workload and the organisational complexity of the surgical team. In order to provide the available information only when it is actually necessary for the procedure, the devices need to recognise the surgical context and workflow [3]. In the field of surgical workflow detection [2], which is also an aspect of the recently defined area of surgical data science, different approaches exist. Some methods attempt to extract a structured model from recorded operations [3], while others directly attempt to use the surgical phases or activities through instrument and sensor data [4-6], laparoscopic video recordings [10-9] or a mixture of these kinematised kinematics [11].

sections.text: RF are a collection of randomised decision trees [12]. Each tree is trained on a randomised subset of all available training data, and in each node only a randomised subset of all available characteristics is available. In this way, all trees in the forest should have a different structure. After training, each tree evaluates each sample and casts one vote, while the majority of votes determine the final classification result. Parameters for the random forest in this experiment were optimised by an exhaustive parameter sweep: the forest consisted of 80 trees with a maximum tree depth of 9 nodes. During training, each node was presented with a random subset of 8 of the 17 available characteristics. HMMs can be used to estimate the internal state of a system based on the trained network structure and to model recorded observations.
